L8bKq0h403yWS0Tl0BxywA.text: Yankees.....hear ye, hear ye! For all my fellow northerners who've been searching for a genuine NY-style bagel shop this side of the mason dixon, you have a very viable option with Poppy's!!  I learned of this place thanks to my trusty Yelp and then instantly bookmarked it thanks to Candyce B's review. I showed up this morning around 10:30 and there was a line that only continued to grow as I waited. Poppy's is small on the inside space so things can get a little cramped as you try to make your way around.  Poppy's offers homemade, kettle boiled bagels. This fact is important because it's one of the things that distinguishes these bagels from the rock solid ones found at Panera and the like. The selection this morning included honey wheat, salt, plain, pumpernickel, everything, and a couple more that I cannot remember. They also have homemade cream cheese available in a handful of flavors. Besides the typical bagel shop offerings, they also serve eggs benedict, omelets, pasta and potato salads, and soup. Again, all homemade in the store.   I ordered the breakfast special: bacon, egg, and cheese on a bagel with a small coffee. I got mine on an everything bagel. You order and pay at the counter and then they call and bring out your order (if it's something that's cooked/prepared) on the side. This was my first time having an everything bagel and? IT WAS EVERYTHING. The bagel was soft and chewy with a light crisp and the flavors didn't overpower the bacon and egg. I had always steered away from everything bagels because I was afraid of the onion/garlic being too overwhelming but this one wasn't. The coffee is serve yourself style and they had french vanilla, hazelnut, dark roast, original, chocolate raspberry flavors alongside skim milk, milk and half and half options.   Poppy's was/is delicious and I'll be back as much as I can when I pass through the area.

zQbTI7_eqyoYCTdQ0XlyRA.text: I was sad when Starbucks moved out and wary when Poppy's Bagels & More moved in.  I thought there was no way a no-name start-up business was going to do well there if Starbucks couldn't make it.  Looks like I was wrong. I've only tried the breakfast bagel sandwiches, but they are excellent.  The bagels are fresh, delicious, and large.  You can get fried or scrambled eggs on them (a nice option that you usually can't find elsewhere), cheese, and/or meat.  For $4, it's a great value, too.  Their breakfast scones and muffin tops look delicious, too, but I try to be good and limit myself to only a sandwich.  Another bonus:  they have flavored coffees!   I've tried the vanilla, but the chocolate raspberry is my favorite.    I've never been for lunch, but the sandwiches they offer sound fantastic, too, and everything in the display case (like a grocer's deli area) looks fresh and good to bring home, too.    The seating can be limited, though, especially on the weekends when we go.  We've been fortunate that it's not hot (or raining) and there's been an empty table outside.  The inside is usually filled with kids/families for breakfast and the seating looks super-cramped.  I'm not sure how it is in the winter.    My only disappointment would be how one person takes your order and then you have to repeat the entire order to the cashier to ring it up. 0dGf8KmL642dFGJUWc1rEQ.text: Poppy's bagels are good but good can only go so far when you feel like you get pooped on week after week by their horrible customer service. LE9Tk33cluA8cL9-1QwuTg.text: I have to say that I came to Poppy's with high expectations based on the overwhelmingly positive reviews but left disappointed. After taking a quick look at the menu, I decided that a bagel breakfast sandwich sounded good and for $4.50 was a decent deal, so I went for the ham, egg, and cheese on an everything bagel. They had a number of side salads including potato salad, pasta salads, and various vegetable mixes but I figured a bagel sandwich would be enough for today and stuck with just that. (They also have some muffins, cookies, soups, paninis, other sandwiches, sodas, and a few different types of coffee). The sandwich came out pretty quickly, especially since they cooked my egg to order, and the worker brought it right to my table which was nice. Upon first bite of the sandwich though I was hugely disappointed. The bagel was very dry and extremely chewy and dense, and did not taste all that fresh. I also realized very quickly that the bagel was way too large for the scant amount of toppings (2 very thin slices of ham, a small egg, and maybe a full slice of American cheese but it may have only been a half slice because it covered only half the bagel). I ended up eating the rest of the sandwich as one open faced half with the toppings and one half plain bagel, but it didn't improve things a lot. I must say that the flavor of the everything bagel was really, really good. It had just the right amount of garlic and onion, and the seeds added a nice touch and didn't all fall off like they do at a lot of places. Unfortunately with the bagel being dry, it still wasn't very enjoyable. Maybe I'll come back to Poppy's to try a bagel with one of their cream cheese options and hope that the flavor of this bagel rather than the freshness is truly how their bagels usually are.

d-33vfXnPjHT9U5IVbvDRg.text: I used to live in Charlotte, NC & I remember when this placed first opened. My family & I always came here because we are from NY and they had the best bagels. My sisters and niece still live there & I travel back and forth at least twice a month!! I will no longer be going there and either will my family ....The lady owner or manager not sure what she was hung up on me and offended me pretty bad.   In 2015 I was diagnosed with Eosinophilic Esophagitis (when your white blood cells attack your esophagus due to food allergies). I can no longer eat DAIRY or WHEAT.  She literally could care less about gluten free people because "they make too much money" and also "they make fresh bagels".  She wouldn't even let me come in to drop off a FREE sample of "NY STYLE" Gluten Free frozen bagels (comes in every flavor) that a lot of NY bagel shops have in the EC.  People who are not gluten free don't understand what it is like to be turned away. Your customers should come first AlWAYS & not be hung up on.  It's not possible to make fresh gluten free bagels and fresh regular bagels (cross contamination). So the best next option is Frozen (if you are gluten free you could relate to me as long as we can eat it we don't care if it's fresh or frozen).  Anyway, I'm offended, hurt and was highly mistreated.   Just a quick fact....  "Today, some 3.1 million people across the United States follow a gluten-free diet. 72 percent of them are classified as "PWAGs" - people without celiac disease avoiding gluten"- Forbes Magazine   Moral of the story if you need to know where to get gluten free bagels in Charlotte feel free to inbox me or follow me on Instagram @yourallergyangel -  Believe it or not some bagel shop owners understand !

Goes somewhat quick though, because they are fully staffed to deal with the morning rush.  There must have been about 25 people in front of me, and I was ordering within 10-15 minutes.  This place is now a carbolicious regular for me, and I'm so happy to be eating some yummy NY style bagels again that taste good!

VEq4IomcSwe6TFxJxBSu-Q.text: I've heard a lot about Poppy's over the last year and finally decided to make the trip today. Overall experience - it lived up the hype. As told by a friend, there is no need to go crazy here. Just like the key to a good sandwich, the X-factor to really setting it apart is good bread. I ended up getting a bacon, egg and cheese on poppy while my wife went with egg and bacon on an everything bagel. Definitely get the bagel toasted as it makes it a bit crispy on the outside and pulls the entire thing together. Also of the two bagels we got, we both agreed the everything bagel was better as it had a great hint of garlic that wasn't too overpowering. Certainly one of the best (if not the best) bagels in the city.   They have a lot of other fun stuff here from pastas to blueberry muffins that all looked amazing. I'll have to come back and try more of the menu sometime. Also I will give them props for having a quick system. We waited in a long line, but it moved quickly. By the time I paid and was getting my coffee, our to-go bag was already ready. While Owen's still holds my heart when it comes to crazy bagel sandwiches, Poppy's is a solid alternate option that I will be visiting again very soon.

OkhW8fXhYbmxsXuyoCBRDg.text: This is a great little place in a retail/dining section of Charlotte that could use a little more traffic.  I hope Poppy's does well for a long time!  I'm not a bagel connoisseur, but I can confidently say that Poppy's are quite good.    I had a turkey on Honey Wheat bagel.  The sliced meat tasted very fresh and seemed to be of high quality.  They use very spicy mustard- -which is awesome.  I ordered mine with lettuce and tomato, both were fine.  The bagel, itself, was just the right level of crusty on the outside/soft on the inside.  It had a nice, nutty flavor too.   The service was okay.  It took a little while, and they seemed a little disorganized, but not a big deal at all. The space is attractive and clean. I am much more of a morning-bagel person, so I look forward to going near breakfast time.

VVS-AKNvm9qw8CQOXPMd-w.text: I'm a bit biased, my store is right across the street from Poppy's so I am eating here quite a bit.  With that said these guys have what it takes and need local love to stay.  Every morning Ronnie, the owner, starts his day at around 4am making everything from scratch.  They don't open till 7 and they close at 3 or 4pm, you do the math, that's dedication to freshness.  The front of house is run by a menagerie of friendly ladies including Ronnie's mother Georgiana.  They do their best to handle your order timely but as some have said they do get quite busy around peak food times--get in a bit before or after for a swift and personable meal.  My staple meal is an everything bagel, toasted, add mayo, cheese, fried egg and bacon or the country ham.  It's rather cheap and really good.  Other times I surf their specials from chicken parma panini or Ronnie will make a slow cooked brisket from time to time which is really delicious.  Easily the best bagel in Charlotte and now their starting to sell them around the area.  If you are a fan of Katz hidden away at the Arboretum them you can enjoy their bagels there.  As a coffee geek I'm a little let down that their coffee service is par to sub par but that's really their only weak point.  One day they might get a coffee geek in their work-staff and then that could turn around.  Otherwise they are family, hard working, and dedicated to good products!

eTU6Q-ClmXbY7aapdM35Aw.text: seating might be an issue but prices are decent and the bagel with lox and cream cheese was great.  Too bad I forgot my left overs in my in-laws fridge when I returned home.

BRXLe6rfJuZptKyraLvccA.text: Oy.  So you're in Charlotte and looking for a bagel.  What to do?  Certainly there are plenty of options but none as good - bagel-wise - as Poppy's.  If you know good, New York bagels then you'll be overjoyed to find Poppy's.  Close your eyes when you bite down into the bagel of your choice and you'll be transported to Manhattan.  They're fresh, often still warm from the oven and simply perfect.  Why a Four Stars instead of a Five?  They're a little (not a lot, just a little) on the high side price-wise.  A buttered bagel is a reasonable $1.50 with tax.  With cream cheese, still pretty reasonable at $2.25 with tax.  But buttered bagel with swiss cheese?  OMFG!  Five frikkin dollars?  Gimme a break.  I thought she made a mistake when I saw the price but she said, "Well, it's four slices of swiss."    No worries.Next time I brought my own slices of swiss and discretely added them to my buttered bagel.  (I'd give em 4 1/2 stars if I could.)  OK, that gripe aside, I've never had anything here I don't like.  If you're Jewish you probably know "kugel" (noodle casserole).  Man, this was the bomb.  Tasted just like my mother made it.  Wow.  Had a mediterranean pasta salad; yum.    There are twin young women who work behind the counter who are a delight.  It's a friendly place and people seem eager to please.  If you're ever looking for me; head to Poppy's on any Sunday morning around 10am and you'll find me there enjoying.

WA9-MsuuadivE2bNLen_iA.text: Friendly and fantastic service. Real NY bagels. Wonderful place!!! I highly recommend!!!

FmmRdxI-MGVHX0Tmjv8m7Q.text: I absolutely love bagels. I know they are not the best for me and I don't care. They are just the perfect carb (which is certainly stiff competition). A dozen of Poppy's finest may have found their way home with us after we finished our breakfast. And I may have eaten one every day this week. And I might have already marked on my calendar when we are going to run out so I can back and get more...maybe.

fB6ZcAZ3Srb0pA0SkwTRUw.text: I was feeling hungry and choose to forego my usual bagel choice and go big with a bacon and egg on an everything bagel. It was good, but wasn't blow-you-away good. Honestly, Poppy's has great bagels, but they didn't wow me with the sandwich. I recommend skipping the sammy and just going with a regular cream cheese bagel. They have a huge selection of flavored coffee, but it's pretty base line. It's a small business so can get crowded inside and the only view of the menu is right when you're up to order, which can be overwhelming on a busy Saturday morning. The patio area is nice, covered with fan, but still can be HOT on a warm Charlotte summer day. I was also a little surprised by their "iced coffee" selection. I picked up the picture and found that the "iced coffee" was super hot, like they'd just brewed it and were waiting for it to cool down or just be poured over ice. Honestly, it's a pet peeve of mine when people offer iced coffee that's really just regular coffee to be poured over ice. Don't offer it if you can't get it right. A customer would rather order something else then have something that is sub-par. Overall, the experience was average, I wouldn't rush back there if I'm visiting the area, but as a local I could see myself grabbing a bagel to go.

5G2EptcQz1qRgnBdBk7RJg.text: Mmmm carbo-licious.   I met the lovely Ms. Tonya P for a brief bagel this morning and 'twas delicious. Carby, crunchity toasted bagels (mmm sesame) and fab cream cheese. The schmear has to be homemade right? Because I dabbled in the chive and the vegetable - both were equally tasty.   Inside Poppy's has a smattering of tables and a cute little patio outside where Riley (my pup) enjoyed some bagel bits off of the concrete. Tasty. Be aware that the patio can be quite noisy with the umpteen cars passing down Providence and Sharon Amity, but no worries, I had my bagel and great company.   Next time I'm in the area, I'm definitely going to pop in and pay homage to Poppy's by indulging in a nice toasty bagel and a pound of cream cheese. Nice to know that there's another local bagel joint in CLT!

1xbczLH92xMj3f3T_sIoeA.text: First time here. Nice location. Plenty of parking. The staff was very helpful. Ordered a bagel sandwich; egg (wasn't scrambled, good!), sausage and cheese on plain bagel. four bagels; two Everything, one Salt and one Blueberry, two individual sides of cream cheese; one scallion and one blueberry, Two fresh chocolate chip scones and two coffees.  Order total was $23. Reasonable. I feel like this was a lot of fresh food for a descent price.  A few more details about the items;  The sausage on the sandwich seemed homemade and very fresh. Not too spicy,but a little heat. Very tasty.  Bagels were large, chewy, crusty outside with fresh airy inside. Everything was very flavorful. Salt bagel had right amount of sat, very good, Blueberry lacked a good berry flavor, so that was disappointing.  The cream cheese appeared to be mixed in store. Both the scallion and blueberry had the desired favors without being overly strong.  The scones were soft and full of chocolate chips. They were very fresh and flavorful. Maybe a little on the dry side, which I think scones are supposed to be, so enjoy with milk, coffee or tea.  Worth the visit for sure.

xN3EEqpXmBbyxVqLo6dGkQ.text: Delicious bagels, friendly service and low prices! My favorite is the breakfast sandwich, but they also have a wide variety of homemade cream cheese if that is more of your speed. They also have soups, salads, and lox, so similar options to Jewish delis that I have been to in NJ. I'm a big garlic fan, so I always get their garlic bagel. It's covered (covered!) in minced garlic, which is great. You may not be able to breathe on anyone afterwards, but it is so garlicky and tasty. My family is from NJ, so I always get the Taylor Ham which I was so excited that they have here. If you don't know what Taylor Ham is, you should definitely try it once. It looks similar to Canadian Bacon, tastes kinda like fried bologna and is sweet and sour. I can't do it justice, but it is a treat in the breakfast sandwich. I think they skimp a little bit on the meat, so I always ask for double Taylor Ham. Like others said, Poppy's can get crazy on the weekend. The parking lot is sufficient (most of the time) but it can be very difficult to find spots if you happen to coincide with classes at Flywheel, which is in the same shopping center. They do a good job of managing the line though so you don't feel like the service is slow.  Overall, it's a great, relatively quick and cheap breakfast choice.

AXiKDShmzUH7prEI9NnAhw.text: I LOVE POPPY'S BAGELS.  When I moved to Charlotte last year, I left behind an amazing little coffee shop with fantastic breakfast sandwiches.  I was homesick for a good bacon, egg and cheese bagel sandwich.  I longed for the perfect bagel, that one fills you up, but doesn't make you feel too full of bread.  Then I found Poppy's, and the bagel hole in my stomach was filled again.  Poppy's is a fantastic, friendly NY bagel shop.  They have all sorts of flavors of bagels, and stock them well into the afternoon - even if you go in right before they close at 3pm, you'll probably be able to get a sandwich on your choice of bagel.  The bacon is always great and not too soggy.  And they'll make you egg white sandwiches too.   They are quick, and always greet you like you're a regular - no matter how long it's been since your last bagel.    I have been hoping that Poppy's will find its way down to the Ballantyne area, but for now it remains my "on my way up-town" luxury.    Oh!  And they have a credit/debit minimum.  So if you're not going to spend $5, be sure to have cash.

WYRyYMk3wnduar3k40gy6w.text: I used to come here all the time, and still do like 1-4 times a month-- just not several times a week.  I need to mention that the bagels are DEFINITELY not the reason I'm only giving 3 stars. If I had only ever had the bagels, I would easily give Poppy's 5 stars. I LOVE the bagels. They're bigger than most places in the area, and the cream cheese doesn't taste overly sweet like other bagel shops where it tastes like powdered sugar was added to the cream cheese.  My biggest complaint is the cannoli. Specifically the filling. I have ordered over 40 cannoils from Poppy's over the span of a year and a half, and literally... not one single time has it been right. Sometimes there is a huge gap in the middle with no filling, sometimes there's just a line of filling and you can literally look right through the cannoli and see what's on the other side. Every time, I say "Please make sure it's actually filled." I literally feel like it's overkill for me to have to say it. I was assured today that it would be completely filled. Guess what?! It wasn't. I've complained about this several times, and stopped getting cannolis because of this, and I was having a pregnancy craving today, and ONCE AGAIN the cannoli was basically empty. I'm tired of them telling me that you can't fill a cannoli all the way. You can. I lived in Italy and make cannolis at home. I have never had "settling" issues or gap issues. You have to spend more than 5 seconds to fill it! That's literally all you do-- you take a little more time, and boom, it's filled! I would LOVE to show the staff how to fill a cannoli, but apparently, they don't need my help. (Trust me, the do need my help.)

y_Dl6cUD2kF75qqs9muokA.text: Visited for the first time recently. I immediately regretted my decision when I saw the long line winding around the interior, but kudos to the staff for keeping things moving. The wait was much shorter than I anticipated, but it did feel kinda cramped in there with the line wrapping around.  I had an everything bagel, lightly toasted, with veggie cream cheese. It was massive and delicious. Loved the fresh bell pepper in the spread!  Since they have "and More" in their name, I probably shouldn't have been surprised, but they do have a ton of other offerings if you're not craving a bagel. I was particularly intrigued by the array of salads in the cold case, and I'll definitely make it a point to drop in for lunch sometime.
